POOF.content: Nietzsche’s address ‘Foes, there are no foes’ requests that we go beyond excuse & pardon, still moves in religious space of benediction or malediction?

TR.content: plea—an excuse, allegation, argument in form of appeal
Austin’s “A Plea for Excuses” is such a plea [performs the “theme”]—in exemplary fashion
Rousseau spent his life protesting his innocence, thus excusing himself, rather than asking forgiveness
Augustine: my impiety divided me against myself, excusing & accusing myself
machine-like operation of excuse: divides/multiplies, drags guilty into repetition of “last word” > eschatology becomes a genre, inexhaustible eschatology of final words
2 meanings of arriver: 1) event that happens to someone 2) message that arrives, or doesn’t, at destination, or unforeseeable addressee > this singular instability plays w/ its own automatism
Rousseau’s text graciously offers us privileged access to machine effect
plus de faute [no more fault, more fault] > vicious circle of excusing & being guilty
guilt as inscription that is ineffaceable, inexorable, inexonerable
de Man: never enough guilt to match text-machine’s infinite power to excuse
guilt in the act of writing, excuse doesn’t merely accuses: carries out the verdict
de Man assumes excuse & forgiveness are the same [?], and that it is easy to say “I forgive you,” he only analyses the one excusing him/herself (not the victim who forgives)
discontinuity will help us go beyond the excuse come closer to event of forgiveness
s’excuser: sometimes deemed improper because it implies excusing oneself in advance, quasi-excuse
via Rousseau, as if one always had to excuse oneself for failing to do so: and once one does, one is excused in advance or condemned forever > madness of this machine (interests us)

PJP.content: ultimate resource/fatality of the anacoluthon: multiplicity of times, instants, interruption time inscribes in “me” > the perjurer can always ask to be excused

WOG.content: to be polite and not speak about yourself could be excuse for haughty detachment
